Award.AbstractNarration:
1742743 Sanders

For decades, researchers have used well-behaved laboratory burners to study high-temperature phenomena. These studies have enabled a better understanding of combustion, which in turn has promoted more efficient use of fuel worldwide. One of the most important laboratory burners is traditionally assembled from hundreds of hypodermic tubes in a painstaking manner that discourages burner surface areas much larger than 10 cm-square. Meanwhile, many researchers desire burners with surface areas of 100 cm-square or more to make new advancements. This project addresses this dilemma by attempting to fabricate appropriate burners in a new way, using additive manufacturing (also known as 3-D printing). Using 3-D printing, it is expected that burners with thousands of intricate internal channels can be produced affordably. Such burners will also be tested in a combustion chamber in this project. If successful, large affordable burners of this type will become accessible to many researchers. This development will be transformative by allowing unprecedented and widespread access to controlled high-temperature environments. Ultimately, numerous benefits will be possible, such as improved fuel efficiencies, improved reliability, and reduced pollution. The majority of this project will be carried out by an undergraduate researcher, offering an outstanding research experience.

Specifically, in this project, the researchers will aim to design, procure, and test a small additively manufactured burner (AMB), followed by a large AMB. While some combustion devices have recently been fabricated with additive manufacturing, to date, no calibration burners have been fabricated this way. The AMB will operate on gas-phase fuel/oxidizer reactants such as methane/air. The surface areas of the two proposed AMBs will be approximately 10 cm-square and more than 100 cm-square, respectively. Large areas (100 cm-square or more) are critical because they offer increased signal-to-noise ratio and minimize confounding edge effects. The proposed large AMB will be at least 35 cm long, so that following this project, it can be used for collection of fundamental laser line-of-sight molecular absorption spectroscopy data with insignificant edge effect bias. The AMB will ultimately be useful for purposes such as calibration of optical and physical sensors, collection of fundamental spectroscopic data, and studies of gas- and solid-phase (soot and particulate) chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are many standard burners other than the familiar Bunsen burner used in combustion research.  One, called a Hencken burner (named after its inventor) is commonly used to produce a flat flame that reaches gas temperatures near the maximum theoretical limit. The Hencken burner uses many needle-like tubes to produce hundreds of adjacent flamelets that together form a roughly flat flame.  Unfortunately, the Hencken design is generally limited to small overall flame sizes, due to factors such as the painstaking manufacturing process.  The goal of this project was to identify a new method of fabricating a similar burner that is scalable to larger sizes; our proposed emphasis was on additive manufacturing.

 

We modified the traditional Hencken design so that each flamelet sat above a slot rather than a tube, to reduce the total number of flamelets needed for a given overall flame area and thereby reduce complexity.  The modified design was manufactured using the additive technique of selective laser melting (SLM). The design was then tested with methane fuel provided to the smaller slots and air provided to the larger slots; representative images are shown in Figures 1 and 2.  Thermocouples and infrared imaging were applied to determine the level of uniformity in the hot gas above the flame.  Uniformity to within 10 K is desired, and while this burner was an initial success, it fell short of that goal, motivating an updated design.

 

There are limitations to additive manufacturing relevant to this project.  Specifically, it is difficult to print the thin sheets of material that our updated design called for. Furthermore, printing large objects (e.g., 500 mm long) at the high resolution desired was generally cost prohibitive, motivating instead an approach based on assembly of multiple printed modules to form a large burner. 

 

Accordingly, the additive manufacturing approach was abandoned about 6 months into the project, and we designed and built a burner based on a folded fin heat sink as shown in Figure 3.  Again, a non-premixed methane-air test flame was produced, which is shown in Figure 4. Results obtained from the study, while promising in terms of affordability and scalability, motivated an alternative approach that could allow for a smaller spacing between adjacent flamelets than what could be readily achieved using a folded fin heat sink. This smaller spacing would encourage more uniform post-flame gas temperatures.

 

The alternative approach involves ~ 100 thin stainless steel plates that are stacked and clamped together. The plates are stacked in an alternating fashion and have cutouts that are strategically positioned so as to deliver air from a common plenum to vertical air channels and fuel from a common plenum to vertical fuel channels. All burner components were been manufactured via laser cutting and assembled, as shown in Figure 5. Testing of the post-flame gas temperatures are not yet sufficiently uniform for our needs, but we have strong evidence that the nonuniformities are due to wrinkling of the thin metal sheets during assembly of the stacked plates. Figure 6 shows a sample flame produced from testing. We have ordered new thin metal sheets, with changes in key dimensions that should eliminate the wrinkling.  In the next iteration of this work, we are hopeful that we can achieve the desired uniformity (+/- 10 K) in the post-flame region.  Furthermore, this design involving stacked plates can be easily scaled to a long length like 1000 mm.

 

The ability to produce a long Hencken-style burner holds numerous benefits. In our application, which is to study hot gases using lasers, a long burner provides high signal levels and negligible edge effects. Once the properties of the hot gases are better understood, sensors used to measure gas properties as in engines can be improved.  Furthermore, there are benefits outside of combustion science as in astronomy, where a better understanding of the optical properties of hot gases is invaluable for studies of stars.
